questions.text: A child is brought to you with complaints of noisy breathing. On examination, you notice the inspiratory stridor in the child, and the laryngeal examination is as below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Laryngomalacia

Explanation:

  • Laryngomalacia is the most common cause of congenital stridor, presenting in infants with inspiratory stridor that worsens when supine or feeding.
  • Laryngeal examination typically shows an omega-shaped epiglottis and redundant arytenoid mucosa, which collapse during inspiration.

Laryngomalacia

Feature

Description

Cause

Congenital floppy laryngeal cartilage, especially affecting the epiglottis and arytenoids

Symptoms

Inspiratory stridor (worse when supine, feeding, or crying)

Onset

At birth or within the first few weeks of life, peaks at 4–8 months, resolves by 12–24 months

Diagnosis

Flexible laryngoscopy → shows omega-shaped epiglottis, redundant arytenoid mucosa

Treatment

Observation in mild cases, surgical intervention (supraglottoplasty) in severe cases

Incorrect Options:

Vocal cord paralysis (Option A): is incorrect because it causes biphasic stridor (both inspiratory and expiratory) and weak cry, unlike the isolated inspiratory stridor seen in laryngomalacia.

Subglottic stenosis (Option B): is incorrect because it causes biphasic stridor and is often associated with prolonged intubation history.

Laryngeal papilloma (Option C): is incorrect because it causes progressive hoarseness and voice changes, whereas laryngomalacia primarily causes stridor without voice involvement.

questions.text: Which of the subsequent laryngeal cartilages is least prone to calcification?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Epiglottis

Explanation:

  • Epiglottis is least prone to calcification because it is composed of elastic cartilage, which resists calcification compared to hyaline cartilage. Elastic cartilage maintains its flexibility and does not undergo the age-related ossification seen in other laryngeal cartilages.

 

Type of Cartilage

Paired Cartilage

Unpaired Cartilage

Hyaline Cartilage

(Calcifies with age)

Arytenoid

Thyroid, Cricoid

Elastic Cartilage

Corniculate, Cuneiform

Epiglottis

Epiglottis

  • Unpaired Elastic Cartilage
  • Shape: Leaf-shaped yellow elastic cartilage.
  • Location: Forms the anterior wall of the laryngeal inlet.
  • Attachments:
    • Connected to the hyoid bone by the hyoepiglottic ligament, dividing it into suprahyoid and infrahyoid portions.
    • The petiole attaches it to the thyroid cartilage just above the vocal cords.
  • Anterior Surface:
    • Preepiglottic Space: Located in front of the epiglottis, between the anterior surface and the thyrohyoid membrane/upper thyroid cartilage. Filled with fat, it may be involved in supraglottic cancers or the base of tongue carcinomas.
  • Posterior Surface:
    • Tubercle of Epiglottis: A bulge that may obstruct the view of the anterior commissure during indirect laryngoscopy.
    • Contains pits for mucous glands and occasional perforations, which may facilitate cancer spread to the preepiglottic space.
  • Clinical Significance:
    • Cancer Spread: Supraglottic cancers can invade the pre-epiglottic space through epiglottic perforations.
    • Non-Essential for Swallowing: The epiglottis can be safely amputated in cases of cancer or trauma without significant risk of aspiration.

 

Thyroid (Option A): The thyroid cartilage is made of hyaline cartilage, which tends to calcify with age, especially after the third decade of life.

Cricoid (Option B): Like the thyroid cartilage, the cricoid cartilage is also composed of hyaline cartilage and is prone to calcification as part of the normal ageing process.

Arytenoid (Option C): The arytenoid cartilage consists of hyaline cartilage in its base and elastic cartilage in its apex, but the hyaline portion is susceptible to calcification over time.

questions.text: Which of the following is not employed in post-laryngectomy rehabilitation?
questions.solution:
The super supraglottic swallow is not employed in post-laryngectomy rehabilitation because the anatomical structures it targets (vocal folds) are no longer present.

 

Vocal rehabilitation-methods:

After laryngectomy, the patient loses his speech completely. The various methods by which communication can be established are given below:

 

Oesophageal Speech (Option B ruled out)

  • In this, the patient is taught to swallow air and hold it in the upper esophagus and then slowly eject it from the esophagus into the pharynx.
  • The patient can speak 6-10 words before re-swallowing air.
  • The voice is rough but loud and understandable.

 

Artificial Larynx It is used in those who fail to learn oesophageal speech.

1. Electrolarynx:

  • Its vibrating disc is held against the soft tissues of the neck and a low-pitched sound is produced in the hypopharynx which is further modulated into speech by the tongue, lips, teeth, and palate.

2. Transoral pneumatic device

  • It is a transoral device.
  • Here vibrations produced in a rubber diaphragm are carried by a plastic tube into the back of the oral cavity where sound is converted into speech by modulators.
  • This is a pneumatic type of device and uses expired air from the tracheostome to vibrate the diaphragm.

 

Tracheo-Oesophageal Speech (Option A ruled out)

  • Here an attempt is made to carry air from the trachea to the esophagus or hypopharynx by the creation of a skin-lined fistula or by placement of an artificial prosthesis.
  • The vibrating column of air entering the pharynx is then modulated into speech.
  • This technique has the disadvantage of food entering the trachea.
  • These days prostheses (Blom-Singer or Panje) are being used to shunt air from the trachea to the esophagus
  • They have inbuilt valves which work only in one direction thus preventing problems of aspiration.

 

Olfactory Rehabilitation: (Option D ruled out)

After laryngectomy, smell is lost because air no longer passes through the nose. This also means patients can't detect dangerous environmental odours like smoke or gas. To address this, a technique called "polite yawning" can be taught. This involves:

  • Lowering the jaw, floor of mouth, and tongue while keeping lips closed.
  • This creates negative pressure in the mouth and throat, drawing air through the nose.
  • Repeating this maneuver several times can help restore some sense of smell and allow detection of environmental hazards.

questions.text: What is a drug called Mitomycin-C used for in medical treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Subglottic stenosis

  • Mitomycin-C is an antineoplastic antibiotic that acts as a DNA cross-linking agent and is used topically in various medical and surgical conditions to inhibit fibroblast proliferation and scar formation. In ENT practice, it is commonly used in the treatment of subglottic stenosis to prevent restenosis following airway dilation or surgical intervention.
  • It is applied topically to the affected area after dilation or surgical removal of fibrotic tissue to reduce the risk of recurrence by inhibiting fibroblast proliferation and excessive scarring.

Rhinocerebral mucormycosis (Option B): Incorrect because the treatment of rhinocerebral mucormycosis primarily involves amphotericin B and surgical debridement, not Mitomycin-C.

Adenoidectomy (Option C): Incorrect because Mitomycin-C is not used in routine adenoidectomy. The procedure involves surgical removal of hypertrophied adenoid tissue without the need for an antifibrotic agent.

Tympanoplasty (Option D): Incorrect because Mitomycin-C is not used in tympanoplasty. This procedure aims to repair the tympanic membrane and ossicular chain, and there is no role for an antifibrotic agent.

questions.text: What is the most likely reason for a patient experiencing breathing difficulties and unsuccessful extubation after undergoing a total thyroidectomy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury

A patient experiencing breathing difficulties and unsuccessful extubation after a total thyroidectomy strongly suggests bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) injury.

  • The recurrent laryngeal nerves supply motor innervation to all intrinsic laryngeal muscles (except the cricothyroid).
  • Bilateral injury causes bilateral vocal cord paralysis in a paramedian position, leading to airway obstruction, stridor, and inability to extubate due to compromised glottic airway.

Superior laryngeal nerve injury (Option A): Incorrect because this nerve supplies the cricothyroid muscle, affecting voice modulation and pitch, but does not cause airway obstruction.

Unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury (Option B): Incorrect because unilateral RLN injury leads to hoarseness, not significant respiratory distress or extubation failure. The contralateral vocal cord compensates, allowing adequate breathing.

Hematoma (Option D): Incorrect because while a postoperative neck hematoma can cause airway compression, it typically presents with swelling, bruising, and respiratory distress within a few hours postoperatively. Immediate surgical evacuation would relieve symptoms, unlike bilateral RLN injury, which persists despite hematoma evacuation.

questions.text: In a patient with laryngeal cancer who has undergone a total laryngectomy, determine the mode of voice production depicted in the provided image.
questions.solution:
Answer: C) Electro larynx

Explanation:

  • Electro larynx: After a total laryngectomy, patients can use an electro larynx for voice production.
  • It is a handheld device that vibrates to generate sound, which the patient then shapes into speech by moving their mouth.
  • The electro larynx is an effective alternative for patients who cannot use a tracheoesophageal prosthesis and provides a mechanical, yet functional, voice.

Electro Larynx:

  • The electro larynx is commonly used in patients who have undergone a total laryngectomy, a procedure that removes the larynx and disrupts normal voice production.
  • The device works by emitting vibrations, which the patient can articulate to form words. Although it can be mechanical-sounding, it remains a popular and accessible method for speech restoration.

Incorrect Options:

Tracheoesophageal prosthesis (Option A): is incorrect because it involves the use of a small valve between the trachea and esophagus to produce speech, not a mechanical device.

Chicago implant (Option B): is incorrect because the Chicago implant is a type of prosthesis used for tracheoesophageal speech but does not directly generate sound like the electro larynx.

Esophageal speech (Option D): is incorrect because this method involves swallowing air and releasing it from the esophagus to produce speech, which is different from using a mechanical device like the electro larynx.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presented with the following X-ray finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Acute laryngotracheobronchitis:

  • Acute laryngotracheobronchitis (Croup): The "steeple sign" seen on the X-ray is characteristic of acute laryngotracheobronchitis, commonly known as croup.
  • This sign refers to the narrowing of the subglottic airway, which appears as a "steeple" or "church steeple" shape on the frontal view of the X-ray.
  • Croup typically presents with symptoms such as a barking cough, stridor, and respiratory distress in children.

Acute Laryngotracheobronchitis (Croup):

  • Acute laryngotracheobronchitis, or croup, is a viral infection most commonly caused by parainfluenza viruses, although other viruses like RSV can also cause it.
  • It leads to inflammation and swelling of the larynx, trachea, and bronchi, which results in airway narrowing and the characteristic "barking" cough.
  • The "steeple sign" seen on X-ray is a diagnostic clue, reflecting subglottic narrowing, which is a hallmark of the disease.

Diagnosis and Treatment of Acute Epiglottitis vs. Croup

Aspect

Acute Epiglottitis

Croup (Acute Laryngotracheobronchitis)

Diagnosis
  • Visualisation: Red and swollen epiglottis (avoid indirect laryngoscopy to prevent airway obstruction).
  • Lateral Neck X-ray: "Thumb sign" indicating swollen epiglottis.
  • Differentiated based on clinical features (e.g., absence of drooling, voice quality).
  • The "steeple sign" on an X-ray AP view shows a narrowing of the upper airway, often seen in croup.

X-Ray Imaging

Hospitalisation

Required due to the high risk of airway obstruction.

Often necessary due to potential breathing difficulties.

Treatment
  • Antibiotics: Parenteral administration (e.g., ampicillin, third-generation cephalosporins).
  • Steroids: Hydrocortisone or dexamethasone to reduce oedema.
  • Hydration: IV fluids if needed.
  • Humidified Oxygen: Via mist tent or croupette.
  • Intubation or Tracheostomy: In cases of severe respiratory obstruction.
  • Antibiotics: Ampicillin 50 mg/kg/day against the H. influenza virus.
  • Humidification: Helps clear crusts and thick secretions that block the tracheobronchial tree.
  • Steroids: to reduce oedema.
  • Racemic Epinephrine: Used as a bronchodilator.
  • Intubation or Tracheostomy: Considered if obstruction worsens or lasts beyond 72 hours. 

Acute epiglottitis (Option B)- is incorrect because while epiglottitis causes airway obstruction, it is typically associated with a "thumbprint sign" on X-ray, not the "steeple sign." This condition presents more acutely with drooling, difficulty swallowing, and a high fever.

Acute pharyngitis (Option C)- is incorrect because acute pharyngitis does not cause a narrowing of the airway as seen in croup, and it does not present with the characteristic X-ray findings like the "steeple sign."

Parapharyngeal abscess (Option D)- is incorrect because a parapharyngeal abscess would present with different symptoms, such as fever, neck swelling, and difficulty swallowing, but it does not typically cause the "steeple sign" on X-ray.

questions.text: Which of the following is a life-threatening nerve injury?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Bilateral Complete RLN Palsy
 

Explanation:

  • This condition leads to both vocal cords being fixed in a median or paramedian position, causing severe airway obstruction.
  • Patients experience stridor and dyspnea, making this the most life-threatening form of recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) injury.
  • Emergency management often requires tracheostomy or vocal cord lateralization surgery.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms does not cause croup?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Rhinovirus

Explanation:

  • Croup (laryngotracheobronchitis) is a viral infection that causes subglottic airway inflammation, leading to barking cough, stridor, and hoarseness.
  • It is most commonly caused by Parainfluenza viruses (types 1 and 2), followed by RSV and influenza.
  • Rhinovirus, however, is primarily associated with the common cold and does not typically cause croup.

Croup (Laryngotracheobronchitis)

Feature

Description

Cause

Parainfluenza virus (Types 1, 2, 3) - most common, RSV, Influenza, Adenovirus

Age Group

6 months - 3 years (most common)

Symptoms

1. Barking cough

2. Inspiratory stridor

3. Hoarseness

4. Respiratory distress

Steeple Sign on X-ray

Subglottic narrowing on AP neck X-ray

Treatment

Mild: Supportive care, humidified air

Moderate-Severe: Dexamethasone + Nebulized Epinephrine

Incorrect Options:

Parainfluenza 1 (Option A): is incorrect because Parainfluenza virus type 1 is the most common cause of croup.

Parainfluenza 2 (Option B): is incorrect because Parainfluenza type 2 also causes croup, though less frequently than type 1.

RSV (Option D): is incorrect because Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV) can cause croup, though it is more commonly associated with bronchiolitis.

questions.text: A 65 year old male presented with history of dysphagia, halitosis and aspiration pneumonia. A barium swallow was done and is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Zenker’s Diverticulum

Explanation:

  • The patient presents with dysphagia, halitosis, and aspiration pneumonia, which are classical symptoms of Zenker’s diverticulum.
  • Barium swallow typically shows a posterior pharyngeal pouch originating from Killian’s dehiscence.

Zenker’s Diverticulum

Feature

Description

Definition

A false diverticulum formed due to herniation of pharyngeal mucosa through Killian’s dehiscence

Cause

Cricopharyngeal muscle dysfunction leading to increased pressure and pouch formation

Symptoms

1. Dysphagia (difficulty swallowing)

2. Regurgitation of undigested food

3. Halitosis (bad breath)

4. Aspiration pneumonia

Diagnosis

Barium swallow X-ray (shows a posterior pharyngeal pouch)

Treatment

Endoscopic diverticulotomy (Dohlman’s procedure) or open diverticulectomy in large cases

Incorrect Options:

Diffuse esophageal spasm (Option A): is incorrect because diffuse esophageal spasm presents with intermittent chest pain and dysphagia, and barium swallow shows a "corkscrew esophagus", not a diverticulum.

Achalasia cardia (Option B): is incorrect because achalasia presents with progressive dysphagia to solids and liquids, with regurgitation. Barium swallow shows a "bird’s beak" appearance, not a pharyngeal pouch.

Esophageal cancer (Option D): is incorrect because esophageal cancer presents with progressive dysphagia, weight loss, and possible hematemesis. Barium swallow shows an irregular stricture with mucosal destruction, not a diverticulum.

questions.text: What is the TNM staging for a patient with carcinoma in the pyriform fossa, presenting with a 5 cm lesion on laryngoscopy, non-mobile right vocal folds, no lymph node involvement, and no distant metastasis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) T3N0M0

Explanation:

The TNM staging for pyriform fossa carcinoma follows the AJCC (American Joint Committee on Cancer) classification.

  • T3: Tumor >4 cm or with vocal cord fixation
  • N0: No regional lymph node involvement
  • M0: No distant metastasis

Since the patient has a 5 cm lesion (T3 criterion) and non-mobile vocal cords (vocal cord fixation), the correct stage is T3N0M0.

TNM Staging of Hypopharyngeal Cancer (Including Pyriform Fossa)

Stage

Tumor Size/Extent

Vocal Cord Mobility

Lymph Node Involvement

Metastasis

T1

Tumor confined to one subsite of hypopharynx

Normal

No nodes (N0)

No (M0)

T2

Tumor extends to more than one subsite or adjacent areas

Normal

N0

M0

T3

Tumor >4 cm or vocal cord fixation

Fixed

N0

M0

T4a

Tumor invades adjacent structures (e.g., thyroid/cricoid cartilage, hyoid, thyroid gland, esophagus)

Fixed

N0/N+

M0

T4b

Tumor invades prevertebral fascia, encases carotid artery, or involves mediastinal structures

Fixed

N0/N+

M0

Incorrect Options:

T2N0M0 (Option A): is incorrect because T2 is for tumors extending to multiple subsites but <4 cm and without vocal cord fixation.

T4aN0M0 (Option C): is incorrect because T4a requires invasion into adjacent structures (e.g., cartilage, esophagus), which is not mentioned in this case.

T4bN0M0 (Option D): is incorrect because T4b involves invasion of prevertebral fascia, carotid artery, or mediastinum, none of which are present in this case.

questions.text: Except in which of the following is laryngeal crepitus not present?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Prevertebral Abscess

Explanation:

  • Laryngeal crepitus refers to the movement of the larynx over the cervical spine during swallowing. It is absent when the larynx is fixed due to an underlying pathology. In a prevertebral abscess, infection spreads in the prevertebral space, restricting the mobility of the larynx, thus abolishing crepitus.

Laryngeal Crepitus and Its Absence

Condition

Laryngeal Crepitus Presence

Reason

Post-cricoid malignancy

Present (unless advanced)

Tumors in this area usually do not fix the larynx early

Hypopharyngeal abscess

Present or reduced

May affect laryngeal movement but not always abolish crepitus

Parapharyngeal abscess

Present or reduced

Can restrict lateral movement but does not fix larynx completely

Prevertebral abscess

Absent

Fixes the larynx to the spine, preventing movement

Incorrect Options:

Post-cricoid malignancy (Option A): is incorrect because early-stage malignancies do not fix the larynx. Crepitus is lost only in advanced cases where the tumor invades deeper tissues.

Hypopharyngeal abscess (Option B): is incorrect because while it can partially restrict laryngeal movement, crepitus is not always completely absent unless the abscess is large.

Parapharyngeal abscess (Option C): is incorrect because this abscess is lateral to the larynx and does not always cause fixation. However, extensive cases may restrict movement.

questions.text: A patient presents with hoarseness of voice. On examination an ulceroproliferative mass is seen on the right vocal cord; the cord was however mobile. There is no lymph node involvement and no metastasis. Which of the following is the best treatment modality for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Radiotherapy

Explanation:

  • In this case, the patient presents with an ulceroproliferative mass on the right vocal cord with mobile vocal cords, no lymph node involvement, and no metastasis.
  • This suggests an early-stage laryngeal carcinoma (likely T1 or T2), where the tumor is confined to the vocal cord without spread to adjacent tissues or lymph nodes.
  • For early-stage tumors of the larynx, radiotherapy is the treatment of choice.
  • It is effective in treating such localized tumors, helps preserve voice function, and avoids the need for more invasive procedures like surgery.

Laryngeal Cancer Treatment:

  • Laryngeal cancer typically presents with hoarseness, which may be the initial symptom.
  • When a tumor is localized to the vocal cords (as in this case), and there is no evidence of regional lymph node involvement or distant metastasis, radiotherapy offers an effective non-surgical option. It preserves the vocal cords and the patient's voice function, making it the preferred treatment modality for early-stage cancers.
  • In advanced laryngeal cancers (involving surrounding structures or metastasis), more radical treatments like total laryngectomy or chemotherapy may be necessary, but this is not the case here.

Incorrect Options:

Total laryngectomy (Option A): is incorrect because the tumor appears to be in an early, localized stage, and radiotherapy should be preferred for such cases to preserve the larynx and voice.

Conservative laryngectomy (Option C): is incorrect because while partial laryngectomy may be considered for certain cases, radiotherapy is typically the first-line treatment for early-stage vocal cord cancer with no spread.

Chemotherapy (Option D): is incorrect because chemotherapy is generally reserved for advanced or metastatic cancers, which is not the case in this patient, as there is no evidence of metastasis or lymph node involvement.

questions.text: A young male who is a professional trumpet blower presented with a swelling on the left side of the neck. On examination, there is a gurgling sound when compressing the swelling. As the X-ray neck was inconclusive a CT neck was taken which is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Laryngocele

Explanation:

  • The most likely diagnosis is Laryngocele.
  • A laryngocele is an air-filled dilation of the saccule of the larynx, which can communicate with the laryngeal lumen.
  • The gurgling sound when compressing the swelling suggests the presence of air or fluid within the sac.
  • This condition is often associated with activities that increase intra-abdominal or intrathoracic pressure, such as blowing a trumpet or playing other wind instruments.
  • The CT scan would reveal a characteristic air-filled structure adjacent to the larynx, confirming the diagnosis.

Laryngocele:

  • A laryngocele is a condition where a portion of the laryngeal mucosa becomes dilated, typically due to increased pressure, causing an air-filled sac to form.
  • It can be classified into internal (confined within the larynx) or external (extending outside the larynx into the neck).
  • Laryngoceles are commonly seen in individuals who perform activities that involve frequent increases in intrathoracic or abdominal pressure, such as trumpet players or other wind instrument musicians.
  • The clinical presentation may include a neck mass, hoarseness, or, as in this case, a gurgling sound when the mass is compressed.

Incorrect Options:

Pharyngeal pouch (Option A): is incorrect because a pharyngeal pouch (or Zenker's diverticulum) would present with dysphagia, regurgitation of food, and aspiration, but it is not associated with a gurgling sound on compression. Additionally, it would be located in the posterior aspect of the pharynx, not adjacent to the larynx.

Tracheoesophageal fistula (Option C): is incorrect because a tracheoesophageal fistula is a congenital abnormal connection between the trachea and esophagus, typically diagnosed in infancy. It may present with choking or aspiration but would not present as a swelling with a gurgling sound in the neck of an adult, and a CT scan would show a connection between the trachea and esophagus, not a laryngeal dilation.

Tonsillar (Option D): is incorrect because tonsillar swelling is typically associated with infections or tumors of the tonsils and would not produce a gurgling sound or the findings seen on CT imaging.

questions.text: A 60 year old patient presented with Hoarseness of voice. On examination following finding shown below. What could be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option B. Secondaries neck: "Secondaries neck" typically refers to the presence of secondary tumors (metastases) in the neck region, most commonly originating from primary tumors elsewhere in the body. Depending on the location and extent of metastasis, it can potentially cause hoarseness of voice, especially if the tumor involves the vocal cords.

 

Incorrect options:

Option A. Multinodular goiter: A multinodular goiter refers to an enlarged thyroid gland with multiple nodules. While a large goiter can cause compression and hoarseness of voice, it is not the most likely diagnosis based solely on hoarseness.

Option C. TB lymphadenitis: TB lymphadenitis refers to the inflammation and swelling of lymph nodes due to tuberculosis infection. While it can cause neck swelling and compression of adjacent structures, it is less likely to cause hoarseness of voice as a primary symptom.

OptionD. Sternomastoid tumor: Sternomastoid tumors are rare and usually benign growths within the sternocleidomastoid muscle of the neck. They are typically asymptomatic and would not be a likely cause of hoarseness of voice.

questions.text: What is the truth about the condition of a 40-year-old male teacher who presents with a complaint of hoarseness of voice for 5 months, worsening gradually, and is a non-smoker and social drinker? Laryngoscopic examination reveals nodules in the vocal cords.

choices.text: Laser therapy is the treatment of choice
It occurs at the junction of anterior 1/3 and posterior 2/3
Requires excision as its potentially malignant

questions.solution:
Correct Option B: It occurs at the junction of anterior 1/3 and posterior 2/3

This patient has singer's nodule based on the history and occupation of the patient.

  • It occurs at the junction of the anterior one-third with the posterior two-thirds, as this is the area of maximum vibration of the cord and thus subject to maximum trauma.

  • Singer's nodule

  • Singer's nodule is a nodule that develops on vocal cords due to excessive or improper use of vocal cords
  • It is common among singers and teachers due to excessive use of cords during their lifetime.
  • The junction of anterior 1/3 and posterior 2/3 is the area of maximum vibration of vocal cords.

Incorrect Options

Option A: Laser therapy is the treatment of choice

  • Mild cases of vocal nodules can be treated conservatively by educating the patient on the proper use of voice.
  • Laser therapy is not the treatment of choice.

Option C: Requires excision as its potentially malignant

  • Vocal nodules are hard, rough, noncancerous growths.
  • They are benign and have no potential for malignancy.

Option D: Most common symptom is pain

  • Most common symptom is hoarseness or rough voice
  • There may be a feeling of lumpiness in the neck.
  • Vocal fatigue from prolonged phonation is another common symptom.

questions.text:
Which of the following are the causes of stridor in neonates:

a. Laryngomalacia

b. Subglottic stenosis

c. Recurrent respiratory papillomatosis

d. Hemorrhagic polyp
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - a, b

Explanation:

  • Stridor is a high-pitched, noisy respiration caused by partial obstruction of the airway at the level of the naso- or oropharynx, larynx and trachea. In neonates, it is usually congenital or due to structural abnormalities.
