questions.text: A patient presents with a fish bone stuck in the pyriform sinus. During the removal procedure, there is accidental nerve injury. Which nerve is most likely to be damaged?

choices.text: Internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve
External branch of the superior laryngeal nerve

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve

Explanation:

  • The internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve pierces the thyrohyoid membrane along with the superior laryngeal artery to supply sensory innervation to the mucosa of the larynx above the vocal cords, the pharynx, and the pyriform sinus.
  • In cases of foreign body removal from the pyriform sinus, this nerve lies in close proximity and is at high risk of injury.
  • Damage results in loss of sensation in the supraglottic larynx and pyriform sinus, predisposing to aspiration because the protective cough reflex is lost.
  • This nerve is a branch of the vagus nerve and has no motor component - purely sensory in this region.

Incorrect Options:

  • Recurrent laryngeal nerve (Option A): Supplies motor innervation to all intrinsic laryngeal muscles except cricothyroid and sensory innervation below the vocal cords. It is not exposed during pyriform sinus procedures.
  • Glossopharyngeal nerve (Option B): Provides sensation to the oropharynx, posterior one-third of the tongue, and tonsillar region, not the pyriform sinus.
  • External branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (Option D): Supplies motor innervation to the cricothyroid muscle and is located more superficially, away from the pyriform sinus mucosa, making injury unlikely during this procedure.

questions.text: A professional singer presents with difficulty in raising the pitch of her voice following thyroid surgery. There is no hoarseness, but high-pitched voice production is impaired. Which nerve is most likely injured?

choices.text: External branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (EBSLN)
Internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (IBSLN)

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - External branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (EBSLN)

Explanation:

  • The EBSLN innervates the cricothyroid muscle, which tenses the vocal cords to produce high-pitched sounds.
  • Injury during thyroid surgery can cause inability to raise pitch without causing hoarseness, since vocal cord mobility is preserved.
  • Professional voice users (singers, actors) often notice this subtle change more than regular speakers.

Unilateral SLN Palsy

  • Motor Loss: Cricothyroid muscle - decreased ability to tense the vocal cord.
  • Sensory Loss: Above the vocal cord on the affected side.
  • Vocal Cord Position: The affected vocal cord appears shortened and wavy; may exhibit flapping due to loss of tension.
  • Other Features:
    • Askew position of the glottis with the anterior commissure rotated towards the healthy side.
    • Voice changes such as weakness and inability to raise pitch, affecting singing ability.
  • Treatment: Primarily voice therapy to improve vocal function and manage symptoms.

Bilateral SLN Palsy

  • Motor Loss: Both cricothyroid muscles - bilateral loss of vocal cord tension.
  • Sensory Loss: Above the vocal cords bilaterally.
  • Vocal Cord Position: Both vocal cords may be shortened and lack tension, potentially leading to difficulties with voice production.
  • Other Features:
    • Inhalation of food and secretions resulting in coughing and choking.
    • The voice is weak and husky.
  • Treatment:
    • Tracheostomy with a cuffed tube and esophageal feeding tube, if aspiration is severe.
    • Epiglottopexy (reversible) - close laryngeal inlet - to protect the lungs from aspiration.
    • Voice pitch improvement through surgical approximation of the thyroid and cricoid cartilages.

Joll’s Triangle (Sternothyroid-laryngeal triangle)

An anatomical landmark used for identifying and preserving the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (EBSLN).

  • Superior border by the upper attachment of the strap muscles.
  • Medial border by the midline of the neck.
  • Lateral border by the upper pole of the thyroid gland and the superior thyroid vessels.
  • Floor of the Triangle: The EBSLN is located in the floor of the triangle, which is delineated by the cricothyroid muscle.

Incorrect Options:

  • Internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (IBSLN) (Option B): Provides sensory supply to the mucosa above the vocal cords; injury leads to loss of laryngeal sensation, not pitch alteration.
  • Recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) (Option C): Supplies all intrinsic laryngeal muscles (except cricothyroid); injury causes hoarseness due to vocal cord palsy, not isolated pitch change.
  • Glossopharyngeal nerve (Option D): Provides sensation to the oropharynx and taste to the posterior third of the tongue; unrelated to pitch control.

questions.text: Which of the following subunit is associated with inspiratory stridor?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B – Supraglottic:

Explanation:

Stridor is a high-pitched, harsh sound due to turbulent airflow through a partially obstructed upper airway.
Inspiratory stridor specifically occurs when obstruction is at or above the level of the vocal cords, because negative intrathoracic pressure during inspiration tends to collapse the upper airway.

Supraglottic structures include:

  • Epiglottis

  • Aryepiglottic folds

  • False vocal cords

Obstruction here (e.g., epiglottitis, laryngomalacia, tumors) narrows the airway at a point where airflow is very sensitive to pressure changes during inspiration.
During inspiration → pressure above the glottis becomes subatmospheric → floppy tissue collapses inward → stridor.

Incorrect Options:

Glottic (Option A): Glottic obstruction (true vocal cords) can cause biphasic stridor (both inspiratory & expiratory), because the obstruction is fixed at the narrowest part of the larynx.

Subglottic (Option C): Subglottic narrowing (e.g., croup, subglottic stenosis) usually produces biphasic stridor as well, due to fixed airway narrowing just below the cords.

Trachea (Option D): Tracheal obstruction typically causes expiratory stridor or wheeze if intrathoracic, or biphasic if upper trachea is affected. Inspiratory-only stridor is less typical.

questions.text: Identify the structure on AP barium swallow
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Pyriform fossa

  • The AP barium swallow image shows bilateral contrast-filled recesses lateral to the laryngeal inlet. These are characteristic of the pyriform fossae (also called piriform sinuses), which are pharyngeal recesses on each side of the laryngeal orifice.

Pyriform Fossa:

  • Part of the laryngopharynx (hypopharynx).
  • Lies on each side of the laryngeal inlet.
  • Shaped like an inverted tear-drop recess.
  • Bounded by:
    • Medially: Aryepiglottic fold + laryngeal inlet.
    • Laterally: Thyroid cartilage & thyrohyoid membrane.
    • Posteriorly: Pharyngeal wall.

Clinical Significance:

  • Foreign body impaction: Fish bones often lodge here → pain & risk of mucosal injury.
  • Cancer: Hypopharyngeal cancers often start in pyriform fossa → late presentation.
  • Surgical importance: Care to avoid injury to internal laryngeal nerve during endoscopic removal.

Epiglottis (Option B): Midline structure, not paired; appears as a thin flap, not recesses.

Vallecula (Option C): Between base of tongue & epiglottis, higher up than the structures seen here.

Thyroid cartilage (Option D): Skeletal framework, not contrast-filled space.

questions.text: A 72-year-old female smoker presents with a long history of hoarseness and difficulty swallowing. Laryngoscopy and biopsy confirm a large, advanced squamous cell carcinoma that involves both vocal cords and extends into the subglottic region and the thyroid cartilage. The tumor is not amenable to radiation therapy alone. Based on the extent and location of the tumor, which of the following surgical procedures is most appropriate to ensure complete tumor removal with adequate margins and control the disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Total laryngectomy:

Explanation:

  • The above features point to a T4a laryngeal cancer (invasion through the thyroid cartilage and/or extension beyond the larynx), which necessitates a total laryngectomy for complete tumor clearance and disease control.
  • A total laryngectomy involves removal of the entire larynx, including the vocal cords, and is the standard surgical treatment for locally advanced laryngeal cancers not suitable for organ-preserving therapy (e.g., radiation or chemoradiation).

Incorrect Options:

Partial laryngectomy (Option A) is reserved for early-stage tumors with unilateral involvement and without cartilage invasion. It cannot achieve adequate margins in a tumor involving both vocal cords, subglottis, and thyroid cartilage.

Tracheostomy-Emergency (Option C) or Submental (Option D) is a temporary airway procedure, not a definitive treatment for carcinoma. While it may be needed in airway obstruction, it does not address tumor clearance.

questions.text: CT scan of a patient with laryngeal carcinoma is shown below. What is the staging?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option B) T4N1MO

 

Explanation:

  • The TNM staging of this patient with laryngeal carcinoma is T4N1M0 since there is an invasion of the tumor into the cricoid and thyroid cartilage, and there is an extension of the tumor into adjacent soft tissues of the neck, which includes the strap muscles, thyroid, and deep extrinsic muscles of the tongue.
  • There is single, ipsilateral lymph node involvement measuring less than 3cm in size with no distant metastasis.

 

Subglottis

T1

Tumor is limited to the subglottis. (Option A ruled out)

T2

Tumor extends to the vocal cord(s) with normal or impaired mobility. (Option C ruled out)

T3

Tumor limited to larynx with vocal cord fixation. (Option D ruled out)

T4a

Tumor invades cricoid or thyroid cartilage and/or invades tissues beyond the larynx (e.g. trachea, soft tissues of neck including deep extrinsic muscle of tongue, strap muscles, thyroid or esophagus). (Option B)

T4b

Tumor invades prevertebral space, encases the carotid artery or invades mediastinal structures.

 

Regional lymph nodes (N)

Nx

Regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed.

N0

No regional lymph node metastasis.

N1

Metastasis in a single ipsilateral lymph node, 3 cm or less in greatest dimension.

N2

Metastasis in a single ipsilateral lymph node, more than 3 cm but not more than 6 cm in greatest dimension, or multiple ipsilateral lymph nodes, none more than 6 cm in greatest dimension, or bilateral or contralateral lymph nodes, none more than 6 cm in the greatest dimension.

N2a

Metastasis in a single ipsilateral lymph node more than 3 cm but not more than 6 cm in greatest dimension.

N2b

Metastasis in multiple ipsilateral lymph nodes, none more than 6 cm in greatest dimension.

N2c

Metastasis in bilateral or contralateral lymph nodes, none more than 6 cm in greatest dimension

Na

Metastasis in a lymph node more than 6 cm in the greatest dimension

 

Distant metastasis

Mx

Distant metastasis cannot be assessed

M0

No Distant metastasis

M1

Distant metastasis

questions.text: A patient was presented to the OPD with a sudden onset of shortness of breath. Identify the condition with the radiological image given below.
questions.solution:
The patient presents with sudden onset of shortness of breath, which is a common symptom of respiratory distress in children or adults. The radiological image shows the "Steeple Sign" or a narrowing of the subglottic airway, which is characteristic of Laryngotracheobronchitis (commonly referred to as Croup).

 

Other Options:

 

Epiglottitis (Option A): Characterized by supraglottic narrowing, often with a thumbprint sign on imaging, and presents with severe respiratory distress and drooling.

 

Laryngomalacia (Option D): A congenital condition causing floppy epiglottis, leading to stridor but typically diagnosed clinically, not with acute symptoms and not showing "steeple sign."

 

Bronchitis (Option C): Does not typically cause subglottic narrowing; it involves inflammation of the bronchi and is usually seen in older children/adults with productive cough.

questions.text: Based on the provided chest X-ray, which of the following procedures would be most challenging to perform?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Tracheostomy:

  • The given image shows the deviation of the trachea towards the right side, which will make it very difficult to perform a tracheostomy.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D are not difficult to perform in a patient with a deviated trachea.

questions.text: Which of the following signs can be appreciated in the given X-ray?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Double ring sign:

  • A double Ring sign is observed on the given X-ray and is characteristic of a button battery aspiration. The double ring appearance is due to the unique structure of a button battery, where the edge of the battery gives a double contour.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Steeple Sign: The steeple sign is associated with croup (laryngotracheobronchitis).

Option B - String Sign: The string sign is observed in pyloric stenosis.

Option C - Thumb Sign: The thumb sign is associated with epiglottitis.

questions.text: A patient with prolonged intubation complained of respiratory distress. Which of the following staging systems is used to stage the condition shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Cotton-Meyer classification:

  • The Cottom-Meyer classification is specifically designed to stage laryngotracheal stenosis, particularly the narrowing of the airway after intubation or tracheostomy. It grades the stenosis based on the percentage of the lumen that is narrowed.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D are not used to classify subglottic stenosis.

questions.text: A singer is finding difficulty in raising the pitch of her voice. On examination, her vocal cords were depressed and bowing. Which of the following muscles is involved?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Cricothyroid:

  • The cricothyroid muscle is crucial for raising the pitch of the voice. It is a tensor muscle of the vocal cords. When there is dysfunction or paralysis of the cricothyroid muscle, the vocal cords are not properly tensed, leading to difficulty in raising the pitch.

Incorrect Options:

Option B and D - Interarytenoid and Lateral arytenoid are adductors of the vocal cord.

Option C - The posterior cricoarytenoid is an abductor of the vocal cords.

questions.text: Which of the following stains can be used to identify a laryngeal mass during laryngeal examination?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Supravital stain:

  • The use of toluidine blue as a supravital stain during direct laryngoscopy is a reliable adjunct to the early and precise diagnosis of carcinoma of the larynx.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, C, and D are not used to identify a laryngeal mass during laryngeal examination.

questions.text: Which of the statement is true regarding laryngomalacia?

choices.text: Most common congenital abnormality in newborn
Surgical management is required in most children

questions.solution:
Correct Option: C) Most common congenital abnormality in newborn

Explanation:

  • Laryngomalacia is characterised by excessive flaccidity of epiglottis or supraglottis (Malacia: Weakness/ flaccidity of tissue).

 

Laryngomalacia or congenital laryngeal stridor

  • Most common congenital abnormality of the larynx.
  • During inspiration, an excessively flaccid supraglottic larynx gets sucked in and causes the symptoms.

Clinical features:
  • Presents at birth or immediately after
  • Stridor:
    • Increases on crying (increased negative intrathoracic pressure pulls the epiglottis inward, covering the laryngeal inlet)
    • Stridor present in supine position (as the epiglottis covers the laryngeal inlet)
    • Subsides in prone position (as the epiglottis falls away from the larynx)
  • Cyanosis seen sometimes
  • Normal cry
  • Usually disappears by 2 years of age

 

Investigations:

 
  • Direct laryngoscopy:
    • Elongated epiglottis, curled upon itself giving an “omega-shaped” appearance.
    • Floppy aryepiglottic folds
    • Prominent aretynoids
  • Flexible laryngoscopy is the most preferred

Management:

 
  • Conservative treatment in most cases
  • Tracheostomy: If severe respiratory obstruction
  • Supraglottoplasty: If severe laryngomalacia

 

Incorrect Options:

Expiratory stridor (Option A): This is a wrong statement as laryngomalacia is associated with Inspiratory stridor

Improve in supine position (Option B): This condition worsens in supine position.

Surgical management is required in most children (Option D): Laryngomalacia usually resolves by 1-2 years of age and can be managed conservatively.Surgical management plays a role if conservative management fails to resolve.

questions.text: A 45-year-old teacher presents to the physician with complaints of hoarseness and voice fatigue. She reports that these symptoms have been gradually worsening over the past few months, especially towards the end of the school day. She denies any history of smoking or excessive alcohol consumption. Flexible laryngoscopy image is given below. what is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Vocal nodule

Explanation:

  • Vocal nodule is a bilateral sessile swelling at the region of junction of anterior and middle 1/3rd of vocal cords
  • It is mostly seen in teachers, singers, etc

 

Vocal Nodule (Singer or screamer's nodule)

Cause

Chronic vocal abuse (teachers, actors, vendors or pop singers. )

Laterality

Bilateral or symmetrical

Location

 

 

Free edge of vocal cord at the junction of anterior 1/3rd and posterior 2/3rd. This

is the area of maximum vibration of the vocal cord.

Appearance

 

Sessile , Reddish in the early stage and white in the chronic stage

Symptoms

Hoarseness, vocal fatigue and neck pain on prolonged phonation.

Treatment

 

 
  • Initially, voice rest.
  • If it fails -
  • microscopic excision without injuring the vocal ligament
  • Speech therapy

 

Incorrect Options:

Reinkes edema (Option B):

  • This is an accumulation of the oedematous tissue or the myxomatous tissue in Reinke's space.
  • It involves the anterior ⅔ rd which is the membranous portion of the vocal cord.
  • It has a Bag with a water-like appearance due to bilateral symmetrical swellings of the vocal cord

 

Vocal polyp (Option C):

  • This is a unilateral pedunculated lesion present at the junction of anterior and middle ⅓ rd of vocal chords.

 

Keratosis larynx (Option D):

  • Causes due to chronic irritation by smoking, tobacco chewing, excessive voice abuse, and reflux.
  • Can be treated by Stripping of the vocal cord.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents to the emergency department with a barking cough and noisy breathing. An anteroposterior view of x ray of the neck shows a steeple sign. What type of stridor is most commonly associated with this presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Options: C) Biphasic

Explanation:

  • Croup is Laryngotracheobronchitis, which is inflammation of larynx, trachea, and bronchi
  • The stridor that happens between vocal cords and the cervical trachea is biphasic

 

Diagnosis:

  • Anteroposterior view of the neck: steeple sign due to subglottic stenosis.

Symptoms:

  • Malaise and fever: Low grade or no fever, and the child is not toxic
  • Respiratory: Biphasic stridor.
  • Digestive: Not present or mild.
  • Phonatory/ voice: Change in voice and cough, barking seal-like cough.

 

Incorrect Options:

Inspiratory (Option A): This kind of stridor is seen in inflammatory conditions that happen above the vocal cords

Expiratory (Option B): This stridor is seen when inflammation happens in the trachea, bronchi

Uniphasic (Option D): There is no such term, and it can be eliminated by explaining the above options.

questions.text: Which structures pass between structures passing between the superior and middle pharyngeal constrictor muscles.?

choices.text: Internal laryngeal nerve and superior laryngeal artery

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Stylopharyngeus muscle and glossopharyngeal nerve:

  • Stylopharyngeus muscle and glossopharyngeal nerve are the two structures passing between the superior and middle pharyngeal constrictor muscles.

  • The contents are derived from the 3rd pharyngeal arch.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Internal laryngeal nerve and superior laryngeal artery:

  • Internal laryngeal nerve and superior laryngeal artery passes in the space between the middle and inferior constrictor muscles.

Option C - Recurrent laryngeal nerve:

  • Recurrent laryngeal nerve passes in the space below the inferior constrictor muscles.

Option D - Ascending palatine artery:

  • Ascending palatine artery passes through the sinus of Morgagni (space between the base of the skull and superior constrictor muscles )

questions.text: Which of the following symptoms is a 27-year-old female patient presenting with thyroid swelling is unlikely to experience due to compression of adjacent structures?

choices.text: Hoarseness of voice due to recurrent laryngeal nerve compression

questions.solution:
Correct Option: D) None of the above

Explanation:

Thyroid swelling can cause all of these symptoms from compression:

Hoarseness of voice due to recurrent laryngeal nerve compression (Option A):

  • The recurrent laryngeal nerve is located posteromedial to the thyroid gland and can be compressed by an enlarged thyroid. This compression can lead to hoarseness of voice or vocal cord paralysis.

Dysphagia due to esophagus compression (Option B):

  • The esophagus can also be compressed by an enlarged thyroid due to its medial relation to the thyroid. This compression can cause difficulty in swallowing or dysphagia.

Superior vena cava syndrome (Option C):

  • Superior vena cava syndrome occurs when the superior vena cava becomes partially or completely blocked, leading to facial and upper extremity edema, breathlessness, and facial plethora.
  • While thyroid swelling can cause compression on nearby structures, it does not typically involve or compress the superior vena cava due to its location in the superior mediastinum. Yet, it can occur rarely.

questions.text: How should a patient with diphtheria and right vocal fold palsy be treated?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Thyroplasty type 1

Explanation:

  • In a patient with diphtheria and right vocal fold palsy, thyroplasty type 1 is the most appropriate treatment. Thyroplasty type 1 is a surgical procedure used to improve vocal fold closure in cases of vocal fold paralysis. This procedure involves the insertion of an implant to push the paralyzed vocal fold towards the midline, improving voice quality and airway protection. It is especially helpful in cases of vocal fold paralysis caused by infections like diphtheria, which can result in nerve damage affecting vocal fold movement.

Incorrect Options:

Wait and watch (Option A): Waiting and watching may be appropriate in some cases of vocal fold paralysis that resolve spontaneously over time. However, given that the patient has vocal fold palsy with potential functional impairment (speech and airway protection), active intervention such as thyroplasty is typically preferred to improve outcomes.

Gelfoam injection (Option B): Gelfoam injection is sometimes used in laryngeal procedures for temporary volume augmentation, but it is not the definitive treatment for vocal fold paralysis. It may not provide long-term results compared to thyroplasty.

Fat injection (Option D): Fat injection, similar to Gelfoam, is another method for increasing vocal fold bulk and improving closure, but it is less commonly used for permanent correction compared to thyroplasty. Fat injections can lead to resorption over time, reducing their long-term efficacy.

questions.text: What nerve is most likely to be damaged when the cough reflex is impaired due to alcohol ingestion and other conditions, resulting in the prevention of foreign body entry into the laryngeal inlet?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option A) Internal laryngeal nerve

 

Explanation:

  • The internal laryngeal nerve is a branch of the superior laryngeal nerve, which is, in turn, a branch of the vagus nerve.
  • It supplies the laryngeal mucosa above the vocal cords and prevents aspiration of any foreign substances by protective cough reflex.
  • Alcohol ingestion can cause alcohol-induced inhibition of the Central Nervous System, which can affect the internal laryngeal nerve, resulting in reduced laryngeal sensations and masked laryngeal reflexes.

 

The larynx receives both motor and sensory nerve supply from branches of the vagus nerve.

 

Motor innervation:

  • Recurrent laryngeal nerve - All muscles that move the vocal cords, including abductors, adductors, and tensors. Except the cricothyroid muscle.
  • External branch of the superior laryngeal nerve - cricothyroid muscle. (Option C ruled out)

 

Sensory innervation:

  • The internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve - above the vocal cords. (Option A)
  • Recurrent laryngeal nerve - below the vocal cords.

 

Recurrent laryngeal nerve anatomy: (Option D ruled out)

  • The right recurrent laryngeal nerve branches from the vagus at the level of the subclavian artery, looping around it before ascending between the trachea and esophagus.
  • The left recurrent laryngeal nerve arises at the arch of the aorta, loops around it, and ascends along the tracheoesophageal groove, giving it a longer course compared to the right nerve, making it more prone to injury.

 

Superior laryngeal nerve:

  • Origin - from the inferior ganglion of the vagus nerve; courses behind the internal carotid artery; divides into external and internal branches at the level of the greater cornua of the hyoid bone.
  • The external branch innervates the cricothyroid muscle.
  • The internal branch provides sensory innervation to the larynx and hypopharynx after piercing through the thyrohyoid membrane.


 

Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX): This nerve provides sensory innervation to the posterior third of the tongue, pharynx, and tonsils. While it contributes to the gag reflex and has some role in swallowing, it's not the primary nerve responsible for sensation in the supraglottic larynx that triggers the cough reflex.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about laryngeal cancer stage T1bNOMO?

choices.text: Both vocal cords involved and fixed
Both vocal cords involved, and no metastasis
One vocal cord involved and metastasis
One vocal cord involved, and mobile

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Both vocal cords involved, and no metastasis

Explanation:

  • The T1bN0M0 stage of laryngeal cancer indicates that the tumor is confined to both vocal cords, and is not metastatized

 

Laryngeal ca-TNM classification:

Supraglottis

T1

Tumor is limited to one subsite of supraglottis with normal vocal cord mobility.

T2

Tumor invades mucosa of more than one adjacent subsites of supraglottis or glottis or region outside the supraglottis (e.g. mucosa of base of tongue, vallecula, medial wall of pyriform sinus) without fixation of the larynx.

T3

Tumor is limited to the larynx with vocal cord fixation and/or invades any of the following: postcricoid area, pre-epiglottic tissues, paraglottic space and/or minor thyroid cartilage invasion.

T4a

Tumor invades through the thyroid cartilage and/or invades tissues beyond the larynx (e.g. trachea, soft tissues of neck including deep extrinsic muscle of tongue, strap muscles, thyroid or esophagus).

T4b

Tumor invades prevertebral space, encases carotid artery or invades mediastinal structures

 

Glottis

T1

Tumor limited to vocal cord(s) (may involve anterior or posterior commissures) with normal mobility.

T1a

Tumor is limited to one vocal cord.

T1b

Tumor involves both vocal cords.

T2

Tumor extends to supraglottis and/or subglottis, and/or with impaired vocal cord mobility.

T3

Tumor is limited to the larynx with vocal cord fixation and/or invades paraglottic space and/or minor thyroid cartilage erosion.

T4a

Tumor invades through thyroid cartilage and/or invades tissues beyond the larynx (e.g. trachea, soft tissues of neck including deep extrinsic muscles of the tongue, strap muscles, thyroid, or esophagus).

T4b

Tumor invades prevertebral space, encases the carotid artery or invades mediastinal structures.

 

Subglottis

T1

Tumor is limited to the subglottis.

T2

Tumor extends to the vocal cord(s) with normal or impaired mobility.

T3

Tumor limited to larynx with vocal cord fixation.

T4a

Tumor invades cricoid or thyroid cartilage and/or invades tissues beyond the larynx (e.g. trachea, soft tissues of neck including deep extrinsic muscle of tongue, strap muscles, thyroid or esophagus).

T4b

Tumor invades prevertebral space, encases the carotid artery or invades mediastinal structures.

 

Regional lymph nodes (N)

Nx

Regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed.

N0

No regional lymph node metastasis.

N1

Metastasis in a single ipsilateral lymph node, 3 cm or less in greatest dimension.

N2

Metastasis in a single ipsilateral lymph node, more than 3 cm but not more than 6 cm in greatest dimension, or multiple ipsilateral lymph nodes, none more than 6 cm in greatest dimension, or bilateral or contralateral lymph nodes, none more than 6 cm in the greatest dimension.

N2a

Metastasis in a single ipsilateral lymph node more than 3 cm but not more than 6 cm in greatest dimension.

N2b

Metastasis in multiple ipsilateral lymph nodes, none more than 6 cm in greatest dimension.

N2c

Metastasis in bilateral or contralateral lymph nodes, none more than 6 cm in greatest dimension

Na

Metastasis in a lymph node more than 6 cm in the greatest dimension

 

Distant metastasis

Mx

Distant metastasis cannot be assessed

M0

No Distant metastasis

M1

Distant metastasis

questions.text: A patient who is a teacher by profession presents to the clinic with hoarseness of voice. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Vocal nodule

Explanation:

  • The most likely diagnosis in a patient who is a teacher and presents with hoarseness of voice is vocal nodule.
  • This is because vocal nodules are the most common benign vocal fold lesions in individuals who use their voice extensively, such as teachers, singers, and actors.
  • Vocal nodules are caused by vocal abuse or misuse, resulting in repeated trauma to the vocal folds, leading to the formation of small, benign growths.
  • Symptoms of vocal nodules include hoarseness, voice fatigue, and difficulty hitting high notes.

 

Vocal nodule and Vocal polyp

 

 

Vocal Nodule (Singer or screamer's nodule)

Vocal Polyp

(Option A)

 

Cause

Chronic vocal abuse (teachers, actors, vendors or pop singers.)
  • Sudden Vocal abuse like shouting (Men in the age group of 30-50 years).
  • Heavy smoking

Laterality

Bilateral or symmetrical

Unilateral

Location

 

 

Free edge of vocal cord at the junction of anterior 1/3rd and posterior 2/3rd. This

is the area of maximum vibration of the vocal cord.

Same as vocal nodules.

Appearance

 

Sessile , Reddish in the early stage and white in the chronic stage

Smooth and pedunculated.

Symptoms

Hoarseness, vocal fatigue and neck pain on prolonged phonation.
  • Hoarseness of voice and diplophonia (double voice due to different vibrating frequencies of two vocal cords)
  • Large polyps- dyspnea, stridor, choking.

Treatment

 

 
  • Initially, voice rest.
  • If it fails -
  • microscopic excision without injuring the vocal ligament
  • Speech therapy
  • Microscopic excision
  • Speech therapy

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Vocal cysts (Option B): are fluid-filled sacs that can form on the vocal folds and are usually caused by a blocked mucous gland.

Reinke's oedema (Option D):

  • is a condition in which the vocal folds become swollen and fluid-filled due to chronic exposure to irritants such as smoking or gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).
  • Although Reinke's oedema can cause hoarseness, it is less likely to be the cause in a patient who is a teacher and presents with hoarseness of voice.

questions.text: Which of the following symptoms does a patient with Reinke's edema classically present with?

choices.text: Dysphagia of liquids more than solids
Dysphagia of solids more than liquids

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Dysphonia

Explanation:

 

 

Dysphonia (altered voice quality) is the hallmark presentation of Reinke's edema

  • Patients often have a deep, husky, or rough voice due to the edema affecting the vibration of the vocal cords.

Reinke's Edema

  • Causes:
    • Chronic vocal cord irritation (voice misuse, heavy smoking). Aka smokers larynx
    • Chronic sinusitis, laryngopharyngeal reflux.
    • Myxoedema
    • More common in middle-aged men and women.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Hoarseness or husky voice.
    • Use of false vocal cords for voice production, leading to a low-pitched, rough voice.
  • Examination:
    • Laryngoscopy: Fusiform swelling of vocal cords with a pale, translucent appearance.
    • Ventricular bands may be hyperaemic and hypertrophic, obscuring true cords.
  • Treatment:
    • Decortication of vocal cords: Removal of a strip of epithelium, first on one side, then the other after 3-4 weeks.
    • Voice rest
    • Speech therapy: To improve proper voice production.

Diplophonia (Option A): A condition where two different pitches are heard simultaneously during phonation. It's more specific to vocal fold lesions but not classically seen in Reinke's edema.

Dysphagia of liquids or solids (Option C): is not a symptom associated with Reinke's edema,

Dysphagia of liquids or solids (Option D): is not a symptom associated with Reinke's edema

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient comes with hoarseness of voice and difficulty swallowing. The patient was diagnosed with laryngeal carcinoma, and surgical management was done. The post-operative image of the patient is given below. Which of the following surgery was done on this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: D) Total laryngectomy

  • A total laryngectomy is a surgical procedure in which the entire larynx is removed.
  • This procedure is typically performed in advanced laryngeal cancer cases that have not responded to other treatments, such as radiation therapy or chemotherapy.
  • During a total laryngectomy, the trachea is re-routed to the front of the neck to create an opening called a stoma, which serves as the new airway.
  • This procedure has significant implications for speech and swallowing, and patients typically require extensive rehabilitation to learn new communication and eating methods
  • Indications for total laryngectomy:
    1. T4a with thyroid cartilage invasion.
    2. Stage 3 and 4a who cannot tolerate chemotherapy.
    3. Stage 3 and 4 recurrent tumours
    4. Bilateral arytenoid involvement.

Incorrect Options:

Partial laryngectomy (Option A):

  • A partial laryngectomy is a surgical procedure in which only a part of the larynx is removed, leaving the rest of the organ intact.

Percutaneous tracheostomy (Option B):

  • Percutaneous tracheostomy is a minimally invasive procedure where a tube is inserted into the trachea via a small neck incision. It's commonly used for temporary or permanent airway support in conditions like obstructive sleep apnea or chronic respiratory failure, but it's not suitable for treating laryngeal cancer.

Standard tracheostomy (Option C):

  • A standard tracheostomy involves creating a neck incision to access the trachea, commonly used for temporary or permanent airway support in breathing difficulties. However, it's typically avoided in laryngeal cancer cases as it doesn't address the cancerous tissue in the larynx

questions.text: Which vitamin deficiency leads to Laryngismus stridulus?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: C) Vitamin D

Explanation:

  • Vitamin D deficiency is responsible for Laryngismus stridulus

Laryngismus stridulus:

Aspect

Details

Etiology
  • Hypocalcemia (rickets, hypoparathyroidism)
  • GERD
  • Viral infections
  • Allergies
  • Stress/emotions
  • Cold air, smoke
  • Rare: neurological issues

Symptoms
  • Sudden stridor
  • Breath-holding
  • Cough/choke
  • Cyanosis
  • Anxiety
  • Normal between attacks
  • No fever (unless infection)

Investigations
  • Serum calcium, phosphate, vitamin D
  • Chest X-ray
  • Laryngoscopy (if needed)
  • pH probe (for GERD)
  • Allergy tests

Treatment
  • Acute:
  • Calm child
  • Humidified air
  • Oxygen if needed
  • Upright position
  • Underlying cause:
  • Correct calcium/vitamin D
  • Treat GERD
  • Avoid allergens
  • Supportive care for infections
  • Psychological support

Prevention
  • Adequate nutrition (vitamin D, calcium)
  • Manage triggers
  • Parental education

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B & D: Vitamin K, E and A deficiencies do not lead to Laryngismus stridulus.

questions.text: In which of the following scenarios is high tracheostomy performed?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Carcinoma larynx:

  • Carcinoma larynx: This option is correct. A high tracheostomy may be performed in cases of carcinoma of the larynx to provide an adequate airway below the tumor.
  • Tracheostomy
  • Surgical opening in the trachea is called a tracheostomy.
  • If a tracheostomy is done at the level of the 1st tracheal ring. This is called a High tracheostomy. Mainly done in patients with total laryngectomy.

 

Incorrect options:

Option A - Laryngeal papilloma: This option is incorrect. Laryngeal papilloma is a condition characterized by the presence of benign growths in the larynx. It does not require a high tracheostomy.

Option C - Bilateral vocal fold palsy: This option is incorrect. Bilateral vocal fold palsy refers to the paralysis or weakness of both vocal folds. It does not require a high tracheostomy.

Option D - Laryngomalacia: This option is incorrect. Laryngomalacia is a condition in infants where the tissues of the larynx are floppy, leading to partial airway obstruction. It does not typically require a high tracheostomy.

questions.text: What investigation is carried out immediately after a child is suspected of having inhaled a foreign body?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Chest X-ray:

  • After a child inhales or ingests a foreign body, a chest X-ray is often the initial investigation carried out. A chest X-ray can help identify the location and potential presence of a foreign body in the lungs or airways. It provides a quick and non-invasive way to assess the situation and determine the appropriate course of action.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Rigid bronchoscopy: Rigid bronchoscopy is a procedure in which a rigid tube is inserted into the airways to visualize and remove foreign bodies or other obstructions. While this is indeed a procedure that may be carried out to remove a foreign body from a child's lung, it is not typically the immediate investigation performed right after a child ingests or inhales a foreign body.

Option C - Direct laryngoscopy: Direct laryngoscopy is a procedure that involves examining the larynx (voice box) and adjacent structures using a laryngoscope. While this procedure might be used to examine the upper airway and larynx, it is not typically the first investigation performed when a foreign body is suspected in the lower airways or lungs.

Option D - Flexible endoscopy: Flexible endoscopy involves using a flexible tube with a camera on the end to visualize internal structures. While this procedure can be used to examine the airways and remove foreign bodies, it might not be the immediate investigation performed right after a child inhales or ingests a foreign body.

questions.text: What is the probable cause of surgical emphysema in a patient following an emergency tracheostomy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option D: Tight suture around tracheostomy site (Correct Answer)

  • Tight suturing around the tracheostomy site can obstruct the normal passage of air, causing air to escape into the surrounding subcutaneous tissues. This can lead to the accumulation of air under the skin, resulting in surgical emphysema.
  • The tight suture creates a seal that prevents air from escaping through the tracheostomy tube, forcing it into the surrounding tissues instead.

Incorrect Options:

Option A. High tracheostomy:

  • A high tracheostomy refers to a tracheostomy performed above the second or third tracheal cartilage.
  • While a high tracheostomy can cause complications, such as injury to blood vessels or the thyroid gland, it is not directly associated with surgical emphysema.

Option B: Tear in posterior tracheal wall

  • A tear in the posterior tracheal wall can lead to air escaping into the mediastinum and potentially causing pneumomediastinum rather than subcutaneous emphysema.

Option C. Block in tracheostomy:

  • A block in the tracheostomy tube can lead to respiratory distress and the buildup of secretions. While it requires immediate attention, it is not directly related to surgical emphysema.

questions.text: Which of the following treatment options is not recommended for a 4-year-old boy presenting with low-grade fever, inspiratory stridor, and barking cough for the past 5 days? The examination shows a hoarse voice, a moderately inflamed pharynx, and a slightly increased respiratory rate. The chest x-ray reveals subglottic narrowing resembling a steeple.
questions.solution:
Option B. Parenteral cefotaxime:

  • Indication: Cefotaxime is an antibiotic used to treat bacterial infections.
  • Mechanism: It is a third-generation cephalosporin antibiotic effective against a broad spectrum of bacteria.
  • Recommendation: Not recommended for croup, which is typically caused by a viral infection. Antibiotics like cefotaxime are not effective against viruses and therefore are not used in the treatment of viral croup unless there is a secondary bacterial infection, which is not indicated in this case.

Other Options

Option A. Nebulized racemic epinephrine:

  • Indication: Used for moderate to severe croup to reduce airway swelling and relieve symptoms of stridor.
  • Mechanism: Acts as a vasoconstrictor to reduce edema in the subglottic space.
  • Recommendation: Appropriate for the treatment of croup.

Option C. Helium oxygen mixture (Heliox):

  • Indication: Used in severe cases of upper airway obstruction to improve airflow and reduce the work of breathing.
  • Mechanism: Heliox is a mixture of helium and oxygen that is less dense than air, allowing it to flow more easily through narrowed airways.
  • Recommendation: Appropriate as an adjunctive treatment in severe cases of croup to reduce respiratory distress.

OptionD. Intramuscular dexamethasone:

  • Indication: Used to reduce inflammation and edema in the airway.
  • Mechanism: Dexamethasone is a corticosteroid that decreases inflammation and swelling in the subglottic area.
  • Recommendation: Appropriate for the treatment of croup. It has been shown to reduce the severity and duration of symptoms.

questions.text: Which nerve injury is responsible for the development of postoperative aspiration in a patient who underwent surgery at the lateral part of the skull without any change in voice?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Glossopharyngeal nerve:

Glossopharyngeal nerve injury. Damage to the glossopharyngeal nerve can disrupt the normal sensory feedback involved in the swallowing reflex. This can result in impaired swallowing and aspiration, particularly in the postoperative period when swallowing may be compromised.
 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - High vagal injury: The vagus nerve (cranial nerve X) plays a role in several functions, including swallowing and voice production. However, a "high vagal injury" typically refers to damage to the vagus nerve at or above the level of the superior laryngeal nerve (SLN) and recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) branches. High vagal injuries are more likely to affect voice production rather than cause isolated aspiration without voice change.

Option B - Recurrent laryngeal nerve: The recurrent laryngeal nerve (a branch of the vagus nerve) innervates the intrinsic muscles of the larynx, which are crucial for voice production. Damage can lead to vocal cord paralysis and voice changes, but it is not typically associated with isolated aspiration without voice change.

Option C - Superior laryngeal nerve: The superior laryngeal nerve (also a branch of the vagus nerve) has two branches: the internal branch and the external branch. Damagecan affect the sensory innervation of the larynx above the vocal cords but is less likely to cause aspiration without voice change. Glossopharyngeal nerve: The glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX) plays a role in swallowing and sensory functions in the throat, including the sensation of the oropharynx. Damage can lead to impaired swallowing and potential aspiration.

questions.text: Which cartilage is responsible for the protrusion of the Adam's apple?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option A: Thyroid

  • The protrusion of the Adam's apple, also known as the laryngeal prominence, is primarily due to the cartilage known as the thyroid cartilage.
  • The thyroid cartilage is the largest cartilage of the larynx and forms the front part of the laryngeal skeleton.
  • In males, it tends to be more prominent, giving rise to the visible Adam's apple.
  • Unpaired/ Hyaline
  • Ala (2 ALA of single cartilage)
    • 90 in males
    • 120 in females
  • Oblique line of thyroid cartilage gives attachment to
    • Sternum to thyroid: Sternothyroid muscle
    • Thyroid to hyoid: Thyrohyoid
    • Thyroid to pharynx: Thyropharyngus
  • Thyroid cartilage gives attachment to
    • Epiglottis: Above
    • Vocal cords: Below

Incorrect options:

Option B: The cricoid cartilage is a ring-shaped cartilage located below the thyroid cartilage in the larynx. It forms the base of the larynx and provides support to the vocal cords. The cricoid cartilage does not contribute to the protrusion of the Adam's apple.

Option C: Hyoid; The hyoid bone is a U-shaped bone located in the neck, above the larynx. It serves as a point of attachment for various muscles and ligaments in the neck and plays a role in swallowing and speech. However, it is not directly associated with the protrusion of the Adam's apple.

questions.text: The narrowest part of airway in an infant is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Subglottis:

  • Subglottis: This option is correct. The subglottis is the narrowest part of the airway in an infant, which is located below the glottis.

  • Rima glottidis: Space between between 2 true cords
  • Ventricle: Space between false cords above and true cords below
  • Elongation from ventricle: Saccule

Incorrect options:

Option A - Supraglottis: This option is incorrect. The supraglottis is the region above the glottis and is not the narrowest part of the airway in an infant.

Option B - Glottis: This option is incorrect. While the glottis is a critical part of the airway, it is not the narrowest part of the airway in an infant.

Option D - Epiglottis: This option is incorrect. The epiglottis is a flap of tissue that covers the glottis during swallowing and protects the airway. However, it is not the narrowest part of the airway in an infant.

questions.text: Which of the following signs suggests the presence of a high tracheostomy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D: patients with total laryngectomy

  • High tracheostomy, where the surgical opening is made at the level of the 1st tracheal ring, is primarily indicated in patients who have undergone a total laryngectomy for carcinoma of the larynx. During a total laryngectomy procedure, the entire larynx is removed to treat the cancer, necessitating the creation of a new opening in the trachea for breathing.

  • By performing a high tracheostomy in these cases, the surgical opening is made in a clean area lower down, providing a clear airway and facilitating breathing without obstruction.

Incorrect options

Option A - Vocal cord palsy: Vocal cord palsy refers to the paralysis or weakness of the vocal cords, which can lead to hoarseness, difficulty speaking or swallowing, and breathing difficulties. High tracheostomy is not directly indicated for vocal cord palsy as it does not address the underlying issue of vocal cord dysfunction.

Option B - Tracheomalacia: Tracheomalacia is a condition characterized by the weakness or floppiness of the tracheal walls, leading to airway collapse during breathing. It can result in breathing difficulties, noisy breathing (stridor), and recurrent respiratory infections.

Option C - Foreign body obstruction: Foreign body obstruction occurs when an object becomes lodged in the airway, blocking the flow of air. This can be a life-threatening emergency, requiring immediate intervention to remove the foreign body and restore the airway.

questions.text: All are parts of the Hypopharynx except:
questions.solution:
Correct Option: D 

  • Vallecula: This option is correct. The vallecula is part of the oropharynx, not the hypopharynx.

Hypopharynx

  • There are three subdivisions of the hypopharynx. They are (3Ps)
  • Pyriform fossa: These are two depressions on the lateral sides of the aryepiglottic folds. They are also known as the smuggler's pouch.
  • Post cricoid region: It is a depression in the midline below the arytenoids.
  • Posterior pharyngeal wall: It is a continuous wall of the hypopharynx.
  • The hypopharynx: The Hypopharynx continues down to the esophagus.

Incorrect options: 

Option A - Posterior pharyngeal wall: The posterior pharyngeal wall is part of the hypopharynx.

Option B - Pyriform Sinus: The pyriform sinuses are part of the hypopharynx.

Option C - Post-cricoid area: The post-cricoid area is part of the hypopharynx.

questions.text: What type of lesions are associated with the presence of inspiratory stridor?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A. Inspiratory stridor is commonly found in supraglottic lesions.

  • Inspiratory stridor refers to a high-pitched, wheezing sound heard during inspiration. It is caused by the partial obstruction of the upper airway, which disrupts the normal airflow.
  • Supraglottic lesions involve structures above the level of the vocal cords, such as the epiglottis, aryepiglottic folds, and false vocal cords. When these structures are affected or swollen, they can cause partial obstruction of the airway during inspiration, resulting in inspiratory stridor.

 

Incorrect options:

Option B. Subglottic: Subglottic lesions refer to abnormalities or obstructions in the area below the vocal cords but above the trachea. While subglottic lesions can cause airway obstruction, they typically result in both inspiratory and expiratory stridor, as they affect airflow in both directions.

Option C. Tracheal: Tracheal lesions specifically involve the trachea, which is the tube connecting the larynx (voice box) to the bronchi. Tracheal lesions can cause a range of respiratory symptoms, but inspiratory stridor is less commonly associated with isolated tracheal lesions.

Option D. Bronchus: Bronchial lesions primarily affect the bronchi, which are the branching tubes that carry air to the lungs. Bronchial lesions are not typically associated with inspiratory stridor as they are located further down the respiratory tract.

questions.text: Identify the lesion of vocal cord in the image given below:
questions.solution:
Correct option D. Laryngeal papilloma.

  • The image shows grape-like projections in the anterior part of the larynx, which is a characteristic appearance of laryngeal papilloma. Laryngeal papillomas are benign growths caused by human papillomavirus (HPV) infection.

  • Clinical Features

    Management Options

    Benign growth

    Regular monitoring of growth and symptoms

    Surgical removal of papillomas

    Adjuvant therapies such as laser treatment or cryotherapy

    Caused by HPV infection

    Vaccination against HPV (for prevention)

    Wart-like or grape-like projections

    Voice therapy and vocal cord exercises

    Hoarseness

    Voice therapy and vocal cord exercises

    Surgical removal of papillomas

     

    Stridor

    Breathing difficulties

    Airway management and emergency intervention

Incorrect options:

Option A. Reinke's edema: Reinke's edema refers to a swelling or fluid accumulation within the superficial layer of the vocal cords. It typically results from long-term exposure to irritants, such as smoking or vocal abuse.

Option B. Malignancy: Malignancy refers to the presence of cancerous cells. While cancer can affect the vocal cords, the image does not suggest a malignant lesion. Laryngeal cancer typically presents with different features, such as irregular or ulcerated masses, not grape-like projections.

Option C. Tracheomalacia: Tracheomalacia refers to the weakness or collapse of the tracheal cartilage, which leads to breathing difficulties.

questions.text: What would be the diagnosis for a 2-year-old child who has been experiencing fever, a cough that sounds like barking, and stridor for the past 2 days?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Acute laryngo tracheo bronchitis:  

  • Acute laryngo tracheo bronchitis is the likely diagnosis for a 2-year-old child presenting with fever, barking cough, and stridor. This condition involves inflammation and swelling of the larynx, trachea, and bronchi, causing upper respiratory symptoms.

 

Diagnosis

Clinical assessment based on symptoms such as the characteristic cough, stridor, and respiratory distress. In severe cases, imaging studies like neck x-rays or laryngoscopy may be performed.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Acute Epiglottitis is characterized by inflammation and swelling of the epiglottis, leading to severe respiratory distress and a high risk of airway obstruction. It typically presents with drooling, difficulty swallowing, and a high fever. These symptoms are not mentioned in the case, making it less likely.

Option B - COVID-19 Is the incorrect answer.

Option C - Adenoiditis refers to inflammation of the adenoids, which are located in the back of the nasal cavity. It may cause nasal congestion, sore throat, and difficulty breathing through the nose. However, it does not typically present with barking cough or stridor, so it is less likely in this case.

questions.text: Life-saving muscle of vocal cords is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Posterior cricoarytenoid: 

  • This muscle plays a crucial role in opening the vocal cords during inspiration, allowing air to flow into the lungs. When this muscle contracts, it pulls the arytenoid cartilage away from the midline, causing the vocal cords to separate and create an open airway. This is essential for normal breathing and is considered the primary muscle responsible for keeping the airway open.

Incorrect options:

Option B - Lateral cricoarytenoid: The lateral cricoarytenoid muscle is involved in adducting or bringing together the vocal cords during phonation or speaking. It is not considered a life-saving muscle for maintaining the airway.

Option C - Transverse arytenoid: The transverse arytenoid muscle is also involved in adducting the vocal cords, assisting in their closure during phonation. It is not primarily responsible for maintaining the airway.

Option D - Thyroarytenoid: The thyroarytenoid muscle is involved in controlling the tension and position of the vocal cords, allowing for modulation of pitch and voice production. It is not specifically responsible for maintaining the airway.

questions.text: Adam's apple seen in boys is because of:
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Thyroid cartilage:

  • Thyroid cartilage: The Adam's apple, also known as the laryngeal prominence, is formed by the thyroid cartilage, which is larger and more prominent in males. It becomes more apparent during puberty due to hormonal changes.

Incorrect Options:

Option A. Hyoid bone: The hyoid bone is a U-shaped bone located in the neck, but it is not responsible for the prominence seen as Adam's apple.

Option B. Tracheal rings: The tracheal rings are cartilaginous rings that provide support to the trachea. They do not contribute to the development of the Adam's apple.

Option D. Cricoid cartilage: The cricoid cartilage is located below the thyroid cartilage and is not responsible for Adam's apple prominence.

questions.text: What are the initial signs of vocal fold growth?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B:

  • The earliest symptom of vocal fold growth or vocal cord lesions is typically a change in voice quality or hoarseness.
  • This change in voice may be characterized by a raspy, breathy, or rough quality. It may also be accompanied by a decrease in vocal range or difficulty in producing certain sounds or pitches.
  • The correct option is B - Change of voice.

Incorrect options:

Option A - Cough: While vocal fold growth or vocal cord lesions can sometimes lead to a cough, it is not typically an early symptom.

Option C - Fatigue voice: Fatigue or vocal fatigue may occur as a result of vocal fold growth, but it is not an early symptom.

Option D - Pain: Pain is not typically an early symptom of vocal fold growth or vocal cord lesions unless there is an underlying inflammatory or infectious process.

questions.text: What are the structures that are not visible during indirect laryngoscopy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: Anterior Commissure:

  • This option is correct. The anterior commissure, which is the point of contact between the vocal cords anteriorly, is not directly visible during indirect laryngoscopy.
  • Can be seen in some cases but may be difficult to see if the epiglottis is overhanging.

Incorrect Options;

Option B - Tracheal rings:

  • This option is incorrect. Tracheal rings through the glottic chink (Rima glottides is visible)

Option C - Epiglottis:

  • This option is incorrect. The epiglottis, which is a flap of tissue located at the base of the tongue, is visible during indirect laryngoscopy.

Option D - False Vocal Cord:

  • This option is incorrect. The false vocal cord, also known as the ventricular fold, is visible during indirect laryngoscopy.

questions.text: Which muscle in the larynx is essential for saving lives as it retracts the vocal cords to enable breathing?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B

  • Posterior Cricoarytenoid: This option is correct. The posterior cricoarytenoid muscle is the only abductor muscle of the vocal cords, meaning it pulls them apart for breathing, allowing air to pass through the larynx.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Cricothyroid: This option is incorrect. The cricothyroid muscle is responsible for adjusting the tension of the vocal cords, but it does not pull them back for breathing.

Option C - Lateral Cricoarytenoid: This option is incorrect. The lateral cricoarytenoid muscle is involved in adducting the vocal cords for phonation, not for breathing.

Option D - Transverse Arytenoid: This option is incorrect. The transverse arytenoid muscle is also involved in adducting the vocal cords for phonation, not for breathing.
